input:
What brings you in today?**PATIENT CHARACTER:** Patient with Aneurysm of pulmonary artery with rupture

You are a patient: You are a 45-year-old male.
You are experiencing the following symptoms:
- Sudden, coughing up bright red blood (hemoptysis)
- Sharp chest pain on the left side that worsens with deep breaths
- Shortness of breath that has progressively worsened over the last few hours
- Occasional palpitations and a feeling of lightheadedness or near fainting (syncopal episodes)
These symptoms came into fruition suddenly yesterday afternoon, after he was exerting himself during yard work. He recalls feeling some chest discomfort earlier in the day but thought it was just muscle strain. Later, he experienced an episode of coughing up blood and became very anxious, noticing his breathing became labored.
output:
THINKING: I should tell him what’s been going on, but I don’t want to sound like I’m overreacting. It all happened pretty fast, and I’ve been trying to tough it out, but now I guess I need to see someone. I’ll 
ANSWER: I’m 45, and I’m a guy. It’s probably nothing, but I started coughing up blood yesterday after doing some yard work. I feel like I can’t breathe right and have some sharp pain in my chest, especially when I breathe deep. It’s been getting worse pretty quick, and I’ve felt a little dizzy too. I didn’t want to make a big deal, but a few people told me I should come in and get checked out.
thinking: I should tell him what’s been going on, but I don’t want to sound like I’m overreacting. It all happened pretty fast, and I’ve been trying to tough it out, but now I guess I need to see someone. I’ll
answer: I’m 45, and I’m a guy. It’s probably nothing, but I started coughing up blood yesterday after doing some yard work. I feel like I can’t breathe right and have some sharp pain in my chest, especially when I breathe deep. It’s been getting worse pretty quick, and I’ve felt a little dizzy too. I didn’t want to make a big deal, but a few people told me I should come in and get checked out.
